basicInfo.notes: Launched February 2010 as Windows Azure, rebranded to Microsoft Azure in 2014. Second largest cloud provider after AWS with ~23% market share. 60+ regions globally, more than any other cloud provider. Used by 95% of Fortune 500 companies. Headquarters in Redmond, WA.

pricing.moneyBackExclusions: Pay-as-you-go; $200 free credit for 30 days; 12 months of free services

technicalSpecs.databaseType: Azure SQL, MySQL, PostgreSQL, Cosmos DB, MariaDB

policiesOverages.hiddenFeesNotes: $200 credit for 30 days (free trial); 12 months free services; Complex pricing leads to bill shock; Support costs extra; Egress charges significant; Deep Microsoft integration but steep learning curve

editorial.knownIssues: Poor Trustpilot rating (2.0) due to billing complaints and unexpected fees; Complex pricing leads to bill shock; Support requires paid plan; Steep learning curve; Non-functional tooling complaints; Credit card removal issues reported; Used by 95% of Fortune 500 but challenging for small users
editorial.bestFor: Enterprises with Microsoft ecosystem (.NET, Windows Server, Active Directory); Hybrid cloud deployments; Organizations needing 60+ regions; Government/regulated industries (FedRAMP, HIPAA); Developers familiar with Visual Studio/Azure DevOps
editorial.avoidIf: Beginner wanting simple hosting; Need predictable pricing; Small projects without cloud expertise; Not using Microsoft stack; Need included support
editorial.competitorComparisonNotes: Second largest cloud provider (23% market share); 60+ regions (most of any provider); Best for Microsoft stack integration; G2 4.4 good but Trustpilot 2.0 reflects billing frustration; $200/30-day free trial; More compliance certifications than most; Hybrid cloud strength with Azure Arc

comparisonData.uniqueSellingPoint: Best Microsoft ecosystem integration with 60+ global regions and leading hybrid cloud capabilities via Azure Arc
comparisonData.idealCustomerProfile: Enterprise using Microsoft technologies (.NET, Windows Server, SQL Server) needing hybrid cloud and extensive compliance certifications

faqContent.faqIsThisHostGood: Microsoft Azure is excellent for enterprises, especially those in the Microsoft ecosystem. G2 4.4 reflects enterprise satisfaction, though Trustpilot 2.0 reflects billing and support complaints from smaller users.
faqContent.faqWhoOwnsThisHost: Microsoft Azure is a cloud computing platform owned and operated by Microsoft Corporation. Launched in 2010, it's the second-largest cloud provider globally.
faqContent.faqHowMuchDoesItCost: Azure uses pay-as-you-go pricing. Basic B1s VM starts around $4/month. $200 free credit for 30 days plus 12 months of free services for new accounts.
faqContent.faqIsItBeginnerFriendly: No. Azure has a steep learning curve with complex pricing. Best for developers with cloud experience or Microsoft certifications.
faqContent.faqDoesItIncludeEmail: No, Azure does not include email hosting. Microsoft 365 (Exchange Online) is a separate product.
faqContent.faqCanIHostWordPress: Yes, via Azure App Service or VMs, but unmanaged. You handle updates and security.
faqContent.faqWhatsTheUptime: Azure guarantees 99.99% uptime for most services with SLA credits for downtime.
faqContent.faqCanICancelAnytime: Yes, pay-as-you-go with no long-term contracts. Delete resources to stop billing.
